ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We met as a lab in a socially distanced context on one occasion, which I enjoyed.
I mostly worked independently offline and virtually, with an occasional check-in meeting with my lab mentor.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This really furthered my observational and analytical skills.
Data analysis in R, making good data visualizations, giving scientific presentations
I learned a lot about a particular area of research: in early adversity brain development.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I absolutely loved the opportunity to work in a lab this semester, and only wish I could continue research for course credit in the future-- it has been critical to my development within the major.

I definitely wish that I had set expectations for more regular check-ins with my lab mentor. For the most part, it felt like I just had certain tasks to complete with no real deadline, and that left me feeling disconnected from the class a lot of the time. I did appreciate that it could be done on my own time, but maybe would have liked a bit more structure. I know that a lot of it is a combination of the nature of the work, as well as my own failure to be more communicative early on.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual lab format felt smooth and natural.

I definitely wish I had more regular check-ins with my lab mentor. Perhaps this would have been facilitated by me going into the actual lab instead of working entirely remotely. Somehow creating more regular expectations of communication may have helped me.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you have the chance to work in a lab, this is a fantastic way to make time for it in your schedule!
If you are a cogsci major join a lab in your sophomore or junior year.

I would! There is a lot of flexibility and so much is dependent upon who your PI and lab mentor are. You get to explore your interests, contribute to research, and potentially complete thesis work all for course credit and a reasonable amount of work.
